docs.lead_paragraph: Paunches, buffalo humps in the neck, puffy cheeks and other unusual accumulations of fat are changing the body shapes of a surprising number of people taking the newer combination therapies to combat the AIDS virus, doctors said here today. How often the unwanted side effect has occurred is not known. But the overall percentage ranged from 5 to 64 in a flurry of reports at the Fifth Conference on Retro Viruses and Opportunistic Infections here.

headline.main: Unusual Fat Accumulations Follow a New Therapy for AIDS

docs.abstract: Doctors report that unusual fat accumulations are changing body shapes of a surprising number of people taking newer combination therapies to combat AIDS virus; complication, which resembles Cushing syndrome, a disorder resulting from overproduction of hormones in adrenal glands, seems to occur most often among people taking protease inhibitors; potential seriousness of problem extends well beyond appearances (M)
docs.snippet: Paunches, buffalo humps in the neck, puffy cheeks and other unusual accumulations of fat are changing the body shapes of a surprising number of people taking the newer combination therapies to combat the AIDS virus, doctors said here today.    How...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration today tackled the thorny issue of financial ties between doctors and the pharmaceutical industry, requiring that physicians who test new drugs and medical devices disclose whether they have received stock, consulting fees or other financial support from the manufacturers. The regulations come more than six years after the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services criticized the drug agency for failing to impose financial disclosure requirements, saying their absence left the Government vulnerable to fraud and abuse.

headline.main: New Rules Will Force Doctors to Disclose Ties to Drug Industry

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration tackles thorny issue of financial ties between doctors and pharmaceutical industry, requiring that physicians that test new drugs and medical devices disclose whether they have received stock, consulting fees or other financial support from manufacturers; critics say new rule, which takes effect in year, is long overdue (M)
